page.title: 16A WALK IN BROXBOURNE WOOD
page.content: Much of the 82 acres of Broxbourne Wood was established in the Middle Ages.Bought by Herts County Council to provide peaceful public recreation & to continue economic forestry it is a Site of Special Scientific Interest. Footpaths & bridleways have been created, a picnic area & carparks. Overall the area is scrub & rough grassland, deciduous woodland & more recently planted conifers. Look closer to identify beech, birch,oak,willows, sallows & old coppiced hornbeams. Ground flora includes bracken,sedges, broom, lichens, golden saxifrage, wild strawberry & ferns. The wood is home to muntjac deer & many birds; robins, redpolls,blackcaps,tits,finches,chiff_ chaffs,to name a few. Abundant wild flowers attract varied butterflies. A walk in this wood is a delight to any nature lover!
